If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f ‚Üí IsCompact k ‚Üí MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

For any integrable function `f` on a generalized `n`-dimensional torus `T(c, R)` over a normed add commutative group `E` and for any `n+1` complex numbers `c` and real numbers `R`, the torus integral of `f` over `T(c, R)` equals the contour integral over the unit circle `C(1, 0)` of the torus integral of `f` over `T(c ‚àò succ, R ‚àò succ)`.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : (Fin (n + 1) ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) ‚Üí E}
  {c : Fin (n + 1) ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ} {R : Fin (n + 1) ‚Üí ‚Ñù},
  TorusIntegrable f c R ‚Üí
    (‚àØ (x : Fin (n + 1) ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) in T(c, R), f x) =
      ‚àÆ (x : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c 0, R 0), ‚àØ (y : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) in T(c ‚àò Fin.succ, R ‚àò Fin.succ), f (Fin.cons x y)
name: torusIntegral_succ
docString: For any integrable function `f` on a generalized `n`-dimensional torus `T(c, R)` over a normed add commutative group `E` and for any `n+1` complex numbers `c` and real numbers `R`, the torus integral of `f` over `T(c, R)` equals the contour integral over the unit circle `C(1, 0)` of the torus integral of `f` over `T(c ‚àò succ, R ‚àò succ)`.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_6 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_7 : BorelSpace E] {f : E ‚Üí F} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {U : Set E},
  IsOpen U ‚Üí
    MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U Œº ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ (g : E ‚Üí ‚Ñù), ContDiff ‚Ñù ‚ä§ g ‚Üí HasCompactSupport g ‚Üí tsupport g ‚äÜ U ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : E), g x ‚Ä¢ f x ‚àÇŒº = 0) ‚Üí
        ‚àÄ·µê (x : E) ‚àÇŒº, x ‚àà U ‚Üí f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_contDiff_smul_eq_zero
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure X} [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts Œº], Continuous f ‚Üí HasCompactSupport f ‚Üí MeasureTheory.Integrable f
name: Continuous.integrable_of_hasCompactSupport
docString: A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

For any normed additive commutative group E over the complex numbers, any function f from n-tuples of complex numbers to E, any real constants C and R with positive entries, and any n-tuple c of complex numbers, if the norm of f composed with the torus map with parameters c and R is bounded by C, then the norm of the integral of f over the n-dimensional complex torus with radii R is bounded by (2œÄ)^n * C * ‚àè(R_i), where R_i denote the entries of R.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : (Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) ‚Üí E} {c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ}
  {R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {C : ‚Ñù},
  (‚àÄ (Œ∏ : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù), ‚Äñf (torusMap c R Œ∏)‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí
    ‚Äñ‚àØ (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) in T(c, R), f x‚Äñ ‚â§ ((2 * Real.pi) ^ n * Finset.univ.prod fun i => |R i|) * C
name: norm_torusIntegral_le_of_norm_le_const
docString: For any normed additive commutative group E over the complex numbers, any function f from n-tuples of complex numbers to E, any real constants C and R with positive entries, and any n-tuple c of complex numbers, if the norm of f composed with the torus map with parameters c and R is bounded by C, then the norm of the integral of f over the n-dimensional complex torus with radii R is bounded by (2œÄ)^n * C * ‚àè(R_i), where R_i denote the entries of R.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` and `R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] (a : E) (c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ) (R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
  TorusIntegrable (fun x => a) c R
name: TorusIntegrable.torusIntegrable_const
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, any type `E` that forms a normed additive commutative group, any constant function `a : E`, and any functions `c : Fin n ‚Üí ‚ÑÇ` and `R : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù`, the constant function is integrable on the generalized torus. In other words, the integrability of the composition of the constant function and a torus map (defined by `c` and `R`) over the interval from 0 to \(2\pi\) (for all components) is guaranteed.
